text: Exodus chapter number 31, Exodus chapter number 31, and I'll be looking specifically for our text verses this evening at Exodus 31, verses 1 through 11, but we will go through many pages of Scripture here in the book of Exodus, and I trust it'll be a blessing to you near the end of the message. We will go over to the New Testament, make some application for us as New Testament believers today. If I were to title the message this evening, I would simply entitle it this, Engaged in the Work, Engaged in the Work. We understand that prior to Exodus chapter number 31, in fact, we will not take time, but if you went back to the 25th chapter of the book of Exodus and read through the 30th chapter of the book of Exodus, that you will have the opportunity to read about the detailed instruction that God gave to Moses with regard to the construction of the tabernacle. The detail that is contained in those chapters of Scripture is phenomenal. Every little detail, every minute detail is planned out and given specifically to Moses with regard to not only the size of the pieces of furniture, but the very substance that was to be used for each of those pieces of furniture. I mean, just great detail is provided in these chapters of Scripture, and we find that the detail that is provided reminds us that our God is a God of order, that our God is a God of details, and what a blessing to see as you study those chapters of Scripture the detail that God provides. It's very specific, very specific instruction, and then we come to this passage that we'll use as our text passage this evening. And as we look at this passage of Scripture, we discover that not only did God give instruction to Moses with regard to the construction of the tabernacle, but we find that God provided the workers and He equipped the workers for this great work. The Bible says in verse number 1 of Exodus 31, And the Lord spake unto Moses, saying, See, I have called by name Bezalel, the son of Uri, the son of Hur of the tribe of Judah, and I have filled him with the Spirit of God in wisdom and in understanding and in knowledge and in all manner of workmanship, to devise cunning works, to work in gold and in silver and in brass, and in cutting of stones, to set them, and in carving of timber, to work in all manner of workmanship. And I, behold, I have given with him Aholiab, the son of Ahissamach of the tribe of Dan, and in the hearts of all that are wise-hearted I have put wisdom, that they may make all that I have commanded thee, the tabernacle of the congregation, the ark of the testimony and the mercy seat that is thereupon, and all the furniture of the tabernacle, and the table and his furniture, and the pure candlestick with all his furniture, and the altar of incense, and the altar of burnt offering with all his furniture, and the laver and his foot, and the cloths of service, and the holy garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments of his sons to minister in the priest's office, and the anointing oil and the sweet incense for the holy place. Notice this, according to all that I have commanded thee shall they do. I believe that when Moses received this word from the Lord, that Moses was greatly encouraged. No doubt as he received the instruction in these previous chapters with regard to all of the detail, the materials that were to be used for each piece of furniture, the specific dimensions and all of the detail, no doubt it could be overwhelming for an individual to receive all of that information. How am I going to be able to do all of this work? And we find that God now comes to Moses, and here in Exodus 31, and he says, I have provided the workers as well. I have equipped them, and I've provided them, and it says here, according to all that I have commanded thee shall they do. Again, I've used the title for our message this evening, engaged in the work. And I want you to notice, first of all, from this passage of Scripture, that these individuals were equipped for the work. They were equipped for the work. I want you to understand that there are two individuals that are named by name. The Bible says in verse number two, see, I have called by name, Bezalel. We find that it also tells us in verse number six, and I behold, I have given with him a holy ab. And so these two individuals in verse two and verse number six, Bezalel and a holy ab, they are mentioned by name. And these men, the Bible tells us, would be equipped for the work that God had given Moses to complete. We find that he calls these individuals, it continues at the end of verse number six, the latter phrase, it says, and in the hearts of all that are wisehearted, I have put wisdom that they may make all that I have commanded thee. So we find that God had equipped the people for the work, and we find that the purpose of this equipping was to do the work. It's very clear as we read the passage of Scripture in verse number three that God says, I have filled him with the Spirit of God and wisdom and an understanding and a knowledge in all manner of workmanship to devise cunning works, to work in gold and in silver and in brass and in cutting of stones to set them and in carving of timber to work in all manner of workmanship. In these verses of Scripture, we find the purpose of this equipping was to do the work of God. They were not Bezalel and a holy ab, and these wisehearted men that are referenced in this passage of Scripture, they were not equipped by God to do this work in any other arena. They were equipped by God specifically for this work. And the Bible tells us that it was God that gave them the ability, that it was God that equipped them. We notice in verse number three, and I have filled him with the Spirit of God, it says in verse number one, and the Lord spake unto Moses. So we know that God, the Lord God Almighty, Jehovah, he is the one that has equipped these individuals. We find that the purpose is stated at the end of verse number six, that they may make all that I have commanded thee. It's again stated at the end of verse number 11, according to all that I have commanded thee shall they do. Now we understand that the instruction had been given in these previous chapters, as I mentioned, by way of introduction. And then we enter into this chapter in which we're studying this evening, and the people are called and equipped for the work. Unfortunately, the 32nd chapter of the book of Exodus records for us the breaking of the law, the sin of the people with the golden calf and Aaron and all of that. And many of us are familiar with that event and that passage of Scripture. We will not focus any of our time upon that this evening. The people then repent, the covenant is renewed, and we find that the construction would begin. But we find that they were equipped for the work, but then I notice as I continue to read through the pages of Scripture that they were engaged in the work. God equipped them, and they, as Paul would say, he wanted to be a good steward of the manifold grace of God, and the reality is that these individuals and the two that are mentioned by name, Bezalel and Aholiab, they are equipped, but then they are engaged in the work. Notice the first word of chapter 36. As we skip through and we notice in verse number 10, the Bible says this, and he made the table of shittum wood. Verse 23, and he made his seven lamps and his snuffers and his snuff dishes of pure gold, of a talent of pure gold made he it and all the vessels thereof. The horns thereof were of the same. We go down to chapter number 38 and the Bible says he made the altar of burnt offering of shittum wood. As I consider the truth of Ephesians 2 in verse 10 in the context of the verse of Scripture, and we think about this truth of good works, and the many people today that have falsely taught some teaching with regard to work salvation, we find that there's no biblical foundation for such a teaching. It is a false teaching. You cannot be saved by good works. The Apostle Paul is not saying to these believers in Ephesus that they ought to be doing these good works so that they can be saved. No, he's already established for them that there's only one way to be saved, and that's through the blood of Christ. No, Paul is not telling them to get engaged in good works so that they can be saved, nor is he telling them to be engaged in good works so that they can stay saved. Both of these teachings are false teachings that are very prevalent today. In fact, there are many denominations, there are many cults that would teach that you have to do good works in order to be saved or to stay saved. Can you imagine what God could do in this world? Can you imagine what God could do in our congregation? If every single individual would say, I'm not content being a spectator. I want to be a participator. I want to be a participant. I want to get engaged in the work. I don't know what area of service, I don't know how I can get engaged or where I can get engaged, but I want to get engaged. It's always encouraging to me as a pastor when someone comes to my office or sends me an email or calls me on the phone and says, is there something I can do for God? Is there something I can do at church? I want to get involved. Oh, that's encouraging. Sometimes it's challenging, but it's encouraging. And I trust this evening that as we look at this Old Testament example and we rejoice in what took place in the tabernacle, that we must be mindful of the fact that there were some individuals that were equipped, but they got engaged. They got involved in the work. And as New Testament believers, we've been equipped. Oh, that God would help us to get engaged. Let us get engaged in the work of the Lord. Father, we love you. We thank you for loving us. Thank you for equipping us. Thank you for giving us the opportunity to serve you. What a blessing. What a joy. We echo the words of the songwriter when he said, there is joy in serving Jesus. Oh, God, I pray that you would help each and every one of us to determine to use our spiritual gifts for your honor, for your glory. Help us, Lord. I pray that you'd move as only you can. For it's in Christ's name we pray, amen.

segments.text: Exodus chapter number 31, Exodus chapter number 31, and I'll be looking specifically for our

today.
If I were to title the message this evening, I would simply entitle it this, Engaged in
the Work, Engaged in the Work.
We understand that prior to Exodus chapter number 31, in fact, we will not take time,
but if you went back to the 25th chapter of the book of Exodus and read through the 30th
chapter of the book of Exodus, that you will have the opportunity to read about the detailed
instruction that God gave to Moses with regard to the construction of the tabernacle.
The detail that is contained in those chapters of Scripture is phenomenal.
Every little detail, every minute detail is planned out and given specifically to Moses
with regard to not only the size of the pieces of furniture, but the very substance that
was to be used for each of those pieces of furniture.
I mean, just great detail is provided in these chapters of Scripture, and we find that the
detail that is provided reminds us that our God is a God of order, that our God is a God
of details, and what a blessing to see as you study those chapters of Scripture the
detail that God provides.
It's very specific, very specific instruction, and then we come to this passage that we'll
use as our text passage this evening.
And as we look at this passage of Scripture, we discover that not only did God give instruction
to Moses with regard to the construction of the tabernacle, but we find that God provided
the workers and He equipped the workers for this great work.
The Bible says in verse number 1 of Exodus 31,
And the Lord spake unto Moses, saying,
See, I have called by name Bezalel, the son of Uri, the son of Hur of the tribe of Judah,
and I have filled him with the Spirit of God in wisdom and in understanding and in knowledge
and in all manner of workmanship, to devise cunning works, to work in gold and in silver
and in brass, and in cutting of stones, to set them, and in carving of timber, to work
in all manner of workmanship.
And I, behold, I have given with him Aholiab, the son of Ahissamach of the tribe of Dan,
and in the hearts of all that are wise-hearted I have put wisdom, that they may make all
that I have commanded thee, the tabernacle of the congregation, the ark of the testimony
and the mercy seat that is thereupon, and all the furniture of the tabernacle, and the
table and his furniture, and the pure candlestick with all his furniture, and the altar of incense,
and the altar of burnt offering with all his furniture, and the laver and his foot,
and the cloths of service, and the holy garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments of
his sons to minister in the priest's office, and the anointing oil and the sweet incense
for the holy place.
Notice this, according to all that I have commanded thee shall they do.
I believe that when Moses received this word from the Lord, that Moses was greatly encouraged.
